transcript:
Therapist: You've been doing an excellent job of recognizing and challenging your negative thoughts, Jamie. As we continue our work together, it's essential to reinforce the skills you've learned and build your confidence in applying them independently. One way to do this is by creating a personalized 'toolbox' of CBT skills and strategies that you can refer to when faced with challenges. What are some of the techniques you've found most helpful so far?

Patient: I've found the thought records to be really useful for catching and challenging negative thoughts. The behavioral activation exercises, like engaging in meaningful activities, have also been helpful in boosting my mood.

Therapist: Those are great tools to have in your toolbox. Another helpful strategy is to create coping cards with reminders of adaptive thoughts, strategies, and new core beliefs. These can be simple phrases or affirmations that you can refer to when you need a boost. For example, you could write, "One rejection doesn't define me; I have strengths and skills that make me valuable." What are some other coping statements you could add to your cards?

Patient: I could write, "Progress isn't always linear; small steps forward still count" and "It's okay to ask for help and lean on others for support."

Therapist: Those are powerful statements, Jamie. As you continue to build your toolbox and coping cards, remember that you have the skills and resources to manage your depression and work towards your goals. It's also important to plan for how you'll support yourself after our therapy sessions end. What are some ways you can continue to practice self-care and access support when needed?

Patient: I can make sure to keep up with my thought records and engage in meaningful activities regularly. I can also reach out to Alex and trusted friends when I need emotional support and consider joining a support group for people with depression.

Therapist: Those are excellent strategies for maintaining your progress and managing potential setbacks. Remember, setbacks are a normal part of the recovery process, and they don't erase the progress you've made. If you find yourself struggling, you can always refer back to your toolbox and coping cards, and don't hesitate to reach out for professional help if needed.

Patient: That's reassuring to know. I'm feeling more confident in my ability to manage my depression, but I also recognize that it's an ongoing process.

Therapist: You're absolutely right, Jamie. Recovery is a journey, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. As we continue our work together, we'll keep reinforcing your skills and exploring new strategies for maintaining your progress. Remember, you've already made significant strides in challenging your negative thoughts and engaging in meaningful activities. Those small victories add up over time.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I'm grateful for your ongoing support and guidance.
